query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 In forma dunque di candida rosa 2 mi si mostrava la milizia santa 3 che nel suo sangue Cristo fece sposa;
4 ma l’altra, che volando vede e canta 5 la gloria di colui che la ’nnamora 6 e la bontà che la fece cotanta,
7 sì come schiera d’ape che s’infiora 8 una fïata e una si ritorna 9 là dove suo laboro s’insapora,
10 nel gran fior discendeva che s’addorna 11 di tante foglie, e quindi risaliva 12 là dove ’l süo amor sempre soggiorna.
query.result:
**English:**
1 In the form, then, of a white rose 2 the holy host was revealed to me, 3 which Christ made his bride with his blood;
4 but the other host, which flies and sings 5 the glory of him who enkindles their love 6 and the goodness that made them so great,
7 like a swarm of bees that flowers 8 at one time and then returns 9 to where their labor is savored,
10 descended into the great flower that adorns itself 11 with so many petals, and then ascended again 12 to where their love always dwells.
**Cornish:**
1 Yn furv, ena, a ros gwyn 2 an milita sans a wra dhe weles dhym, 3 hag a wrug Krist y wrek yn y wos gans y wos.
4 Mes an milita arall, hag a wra dhe hedhes ha dhe gana 5 an gloyr a neb a wra dhe amori, 6 ha’n vonder a wrug y avel hyn kemmys,
7 kepar ha skwadron a geyn a wra dhe bleujyow 8 yn termyn unn ha unn a wra dhe dhedhes 9 ena le may y wra dhe savori y obor,
10 a wra dhe disken yn an vras bleujyn hag a wra dhe addorni 11 gans moy ages delyow, ha ena a wra dhe vos dhegor 12 ena le may y wra y garow bys vyth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 Le facce tutte avean di fiamma viva 14 e l’ali d’oro, e l’altro tanto bianco, 15 che nulla neve a quel termine arriva.
query.result:
**English:**
13 Their faces all had the color of living flame, 14 their wings were gold, and the rest so white, 15 that no snow reaches that degree.
**Cornish:**
13 An feythow oll o color flamm byw 14 ha’n eskel a our, ha’n arall kemmys gwynn, 15 bys na wra nag eira dhe’n termyn hyn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
16 Quando scendean nel fior, di banco in banco 17 porgevan de la pace e de l’ardore 18 ch’elli acquistavan ventilando il fianco.
query.result:
**English:**
16 When they descended into the flower, from bench to bench, 17 they offered peace and the burning love 18 that they acquired by fanning their sides.
**Cornish:**
16 Pyth esedhons yn keffrys, a venk dhe venk, 17 aga rens pes ha bos ha'gas karanteth 18 aga gavasons gans flappya aga kylgh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
19 Né l’interporsi tra ’l disopra e ’l fiore 20 di tanta moltitudine volante 21 impediva la vista e lo splendore:
22 ché la luce divina è penetrante 23 per l’universo secondo ch’è degno, 24 sì che nulla le puote essere ostante.
query.result:
**English:**
19 Nor did the interposition between the above and the flower 20 of such a flying multitude 21 impede the sight and the splendor:
22 for the divine light is penetrating 23 through the universe according to its worthiness, 24 so that nothing can obstruct it.
**Cornish:**
19 Ha'gas keffrys a-dro dhe'n bleujen 20 a-dro dhe'n niver a-hedhans 21 na lettyas an golwg ha'gas splannder:
22 Rag an golwg dowlek yw treusdreus 23 a-dreus an bys vythyn yw dygthys, 24 marnas na allo dheth nep tra veur.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 Questo sicuro e gaudïoso regno, 26 frequente in gente antica e in novella, 27 viso e amore avea tutto ad un segno.
query.result:
**English:**
25 This secure and joyful kingdom, 26 frequented by people of old and new, 27 had its vision and love directed to one goal.
**Cornish:**
25 An wlas sur ha lowenys ma, 26 leun gans tus a-goos ha nowyth, 27 aga golwg ha karanteth o onn arnodha.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 O trina luce che ’n unica stella 29 scintillando a lor vista, sì li appaga! 30 guarda qua giuso a la nostra procella!
31 Se i barbari, venendo da tal plaga 32 che ciascun giorno d’Elice si cuopra, 33 rotante col suo figlio ond’ ella è vaga,
34 veggendo Roma e l’ardüa sua opra, 35 stupefaciensi, quando Laterano 36 a le cose mortali andò di sopra;
37 ïo, che al divino da l’umano, 38 a l’etterno dal tempo era venuto, 39 e di Fiorenza in popol giusto e sano,
40 di che stupor dovea esser compiuto! 41 Certo tra esso e ’l gaudio mi facea 42 libito non udire e starmi muto.
query.result:
**English:**
28 O threefold light that, shining in a single star, 29 scintillates before their sight and so satisfies them! 30 Look down here at our tempest!
31 If the barbarians, coming from such a region 32 that every day is covered by the constellation of Ursa Major, 33 rotating with its son around which it revolves,
34 seeing Rome and its arduous work, 35 were astounded when the Lateran 36 surpassed all mortal things;
37 I, who had come from the human to the divine, 38 from time to eternity, 39 and from Florence to a just and healthy people,
40 with what astonishment should I have been filled! 41 Certainly, between that and the joy, 42 I felt a desire not to hear and to remain silent.
**Cornish:**
28 O golwg teyr a-gledh yn un steren, 29 ow skynnja rag golwg, ha'gas lowen! 30 Sel gwel an pow an-ma's!
31 Mar an варваријанј, ow tos a'n pow 32 le mayn dydh yw kudhys gans Ursa Major, 33 ow trohe gans aga mab a-dro dhe'n steren,
34 ow tos Roma ha aga ober krev, 35 o synjys veu aga hwartha, pan wrug an Lateran 36 drehedhes dhe'n traow marow;
37 Vy, ow tos a'n dowlek a'n denel, 38 a'n bys vythyn a'n amser, 39 ha a Florens dhe bobel just ha iach,
40 pyth o synjys veu vy leun! 41 Yn-mesk, ynter an synjys ha'n lowen, 42 vy o synjys na gowsons klevs ha bos mudh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
43 E quasi peregrin che si ricrea 44 nel tempio del suo voto riguardando, 45 e spera già ridir com’ ello stea,
46 su per la viva luce passeggiando, 47 menava ïo li occhi per li gradi, 48 mo sù, mo giù e mo recirculando.
query.result:
**English:**
43 And like a pilgrim who rejoices 44 in the temple of his vow, looking around, 45 and already hopes to tell again how it was,
46 I, walking over the living light, 47 moved my eyes over the tiers, 48 now up, now down, and now circling around.
**Cornish:**
43 Ha kepar pererin ow lowen 44 yn-mes an tempel a'y vudh, ow tos war-dro, 45 ha'gas spyr dhe dhiskwedhes pyth o veu,
46 war-barth an golwg byw ow kerdhes, 47 ow treylya vy lagha a-dreus an radh, 48 weyth dhe-ves, weyth dhe-woles, ha weyth ow trohe war-dro.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Vedëa visi a carità süadi, 50 d’altrui lume fregiati e di suo riso, 51 e atti ornati di tutte onestadi.
query.result:
**English:**
49 I saw faces made beautiful by charity, 50 adorned with the light of others and with their own smiles, 51 and their actions adorned with all virtues.
**Cornish:**
49 Yth wely vy golwg a-gleudhys gans karanteth, 50 ow tyski gans golwg eryll ha gans aga smial, 51 ha aga oberow ow tyski gans pub tra voes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 Uno intendëa, e altro mi rispuose: 59 credea veder Beatrice e vidi un sene 60 vestito con le genti glorïose.
query.result:
**English:**
58 I was thinking of one thing, and another answered me: 59 I thought to see Beatrice and I saw an elder 60 clothed with the glorious people.
**Cornish:**
58 Vy o komprehendya unn tra, ha aral a-rag gavas: 59 Vy o kredya gwel Beatrice ha vy a welas unn koth, 60 ow tyski gans an bobel a-gleudhys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 Diffuso era per li occhi e per le gene 62 di benigna letizia, in atto pio 63 quale a tenero padre si convene.
query.result:
**English:**
61 Diffused over his eyes and cheeks 62 was a benign joy, in a pious manner 63 as befits a tender father.
**Cornish:**
61 O leudhya war-barth y lagha ha'y dhewyn 62 o lowen benyn, yn-mes unn ober piow 63 kepar ha'n tas tener.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 Sanza risponder, li occhi sù levai, 71 e vidi lei che si facea corona 72 reflettendo da sé li etterni rai.
query.result:
**English:**
70 Without answering, I raised my eyes, 71 and saw her who was making a crown for herself, 72 reflecting from herself the eternal rays.
**Cornish:**
70 Heb responna, y'm lagha a gafas, 71 ha'm gwelas hi ow tos ow honan, 72 ow tysplegya an gwythenn sempeternel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
73 Da quella regïon che più sù tona 74 occhio mortale alcun tanto non dista, 75 qualunque in mare più giù s’abbandona,
76 quanto lì da Beatrice la mia vista; 77 ma nulla mi facea, ché süa effige 78 non discendëa a me per mezzo mista.
query.result:
**English:**
73 From that region which thunders highest, 74 no mortal eye is so far distant, 75 no matter how far down into the sea one descends,
76 as my sight was there from Beatrice; 77 but nothing hindered me, for her image 78 did not descend to me mixed through a medium.
**Cornish:**
73 A-dhyworth an pow an moyha tonna, 74 nag eus lagha mortal ken nag esa, 75 pyth ken nag esa moyha i'n mor,
76 avelsa ow vewa a Vyatrys; 77 mes nag eus travia vy, rag y honan 78 nag eus diskenn dhe'm dre es.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 «O donna in cui la mia speranza vige, 80 e che soffristi per la mia salute 81 in inferno lasciar le tue vestige,
82 di tante cose quant’ i’ ho vedute, 83 dal tuo podere e da la tua bontate 84 riconosco la grazia e la virtute.
query.result:
**English:**
79 "O lady in whom my hope flourishes, 80 and who suffered for my salvation 81 leaving your footprints in hell,
82 of so many things as I have seen, 83 from your power and from your goodness 84 I recognize the grace and the virtue.
**Cornish:**
79 "O benen, yn aga yma fy spyrans, 80 ha th'a dhuggas rag fy iechydh 81 dhe hedha dhis lymmyn yn ifern,
82 a-ugh an traowow a'm gwelas, 83 a'th alus ha'th dhadhra 84 yma'm aswon an ras ha'n nerth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 Tu m’hai di servo tratto a libertate 86 per tutte quelle vie, per tutt’ i modi 87 che di ciò fare avei la potestate.
query.result:
**English:**
85 You have drawn me from servitude to liberty 86 through all those ways, through all those modes 87 by which you had the power to do so.
**Cornish:**
85 Th'y'm gwrug a servys dhe'm gorra dhe frank, 86 a-dre oll an fordhow, a-dre oll an fordhow 87 a-dhyworth an gallos owth eus an alus.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 La tua magnificenza in me custodi, 89 sì che l’anima mia, che fatt’ hai sana, 90 piacente a te dal corpo si disnodi».
query.result:
**English:**
88 Preserve your magnificence in me, 89 so that my soul, which you have made whole, 90 may be pleasing to you when it is untied from the body.
**Cornish:**
88 Gwith orth an brassa dhe'm gorra, 89 rag an enef va, th'y'th gorra iach, 90 a vi dhe blys pan vo dhe'n korf.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 Così orai; e quella, sì lontana 92 come parea, sorrise e riguardommi; 93 poi si tornò a l’etterna fontana.
query.result:
**English:**
91 Thus I prayed; and she, as distant 92 as she seemed, smiled and looked at me; 93 then she turned back to the eternal fountain.
**Cornish:**
91 Vel dh'y leveris; ha hitho, kyns pell, 92 a welas, a wrisa ha'm gwelas; 93 wosa henna hi a dheuth dhe'n fenten sempeternel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 E ’l santo sene: «Acciò che tu assommi 95 perfettamente», disse, «il tuo cammino, 96 a che priego e amor santo mandommi,
97 vola con li occhi per questo giardino; 98 ché veder lui t’acconcerà lo sguardo 99 più al montar per lo raggio divino.
query.result:
**English:**
94 And the holy elder said: "In order that you may complete 95 your journey perfectly," he said, "to which holy love and prayer 96 have sent me,
97 fly with your eyes through this garden; 98 for seeing it will prepare your gaze 99 to ascend further by the divine ray.
**Cornish:**
94 Ha'n sans vynten: "Rag bos dhe wul henna 95 yn berfekth, leveris," ev a leveris, "an fordh va, 96 dhe'n pedynnans ha'n karanteth sans m'y thrug,
97 hedha'n lagha a-dre an arlow ma, 98 rag y weles a wul bos dhe'th weles 99 dhe wul mos dhe vos dhe'n gwythenn dhiwin."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 E la regina del cielo, ond’ ïo ardo 101 tutto d’amor, ne farà ogne grazia, 102 però ch’i’ sono il suo fedel Bernardo».
query.result:
**English:**
100 And the queen of heaven, for whom I burn 101 all with love, will grant you every grace, 102 because I am her faithful Bernard."
**Cornish:**
100 Ha'n vrenhynes a'n nev, rag aga yma'm tan, 101 oll a garanteth, a wra dhe'th pub gras, 102 rag y'm ow feythful Varnard."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 Qual è colui che forse di Croazia 104 viene a veder la Veronica nostra, 105 che per l’antica fame non sen sazia,
106 ma dice nel pensier, fin che si mostra: 107 ‘Segnor mio Iesù Cristo, Dio verace, 108 or fu sì fatta la sembianza vostra?’;
109 tal era io mirando la vivace 110 carità di colui che ’n questo mondo, 111 contemplando, gustò di quella pace.
query.result:
**English:**
103 Like one who perhaps comes from Croatia 104 to see our Veronica, 105 who is not sated by the ancient hunger,
106 but says in his thoughts, as long as it is shown: 107 "My Lord Jesus Christ, true God, 108 was your likeness really like this?"
109 Such was I, gazing at the living 110 charity of him who, in this world, 111 contemplating, tasted of that peace.
**Cornish:**
103 Kepar ha nen a dheuth mar a Groati, 104 dhe weles an Veronika agan, 105 na wra dhe'n hen nauns mar dheugh,
106 mes a lever yn y vynans, pub tra veur: 107 "O Arluth Iesu Krist, Gwir Vow, 108 o veur dhe'th semlans kepar hemma?"
109 Vel henna o veur karanteth byw, 110 a'n nen a dheuth yn an bys ma, 111 owth omdhiskwedhes, a dheuth dhe'n peth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 Io levai li occhi; e come da mattina 119 la parte orïental de l’orizzonte 120 soverchia quella dove ’l sol declina,
121 così, quasi di valle andando a monte 122 con li occhi, vidi parte ne lo stremo 123 vincer di lume tutta l’altra fronte.
query.result:
**English:**
118 I lifted my eyes; and as in the morning 119 the eastern part of the horizon 120 surpasses that where the sun declines,
121 so, almost going from valley to mountain 122 with my eyes, I saw a part at the edge 123 overcome all the other brow with light.
**Cornish:**
118 Y'm skoodhas vy lagha; havel orth an myttyn 119 an rannvro dornow an orynt 120 a wra dhe'n rannvro may hy'n howl an howl,
121 vel, orth a-dhallath a-dhyworth dhe'n chi 122 gans vy lagha, y'm gwelas rannvro yn penn 123 ow trehedhes oll an aral gans golow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 E come quivi ove s’aspetta il temo 125 che mal guidò Fetonte, più s’infiamma, 126 e quinci e quindi il lume si fa scemo,
127 così quella pacifica oriafiamma 128 nel mezzo s’avvivava, e d’ogne parte 129 per igual modo allentava la fiamma;
130 e a quel mezzo, con le penne sparte, 131 vid’ io più di mille angeli festanti, 132 ciascun distinto di fulgore e d’arte.
query.result:
**English:**
124 And as there where the chariot is awaited 125 that Phaethon badly guided, it becomes more inflamed, 126 and on this side and that the light grows weaker,
127 so that peaceful eastern flame 128 grew brighter in the middle, and on every side 129 the flame weakened equally;
130 and in that middle, with their wings spread, 131 I saw more than a thousand joyful angels, 132 each distinct in brilliance and artistry.
**Cornish:**
124 Ha gwell orth le may aswonn an kar 125 a veu Faethon yn drog-rewlya, moyha'n tanow, 126 ha war-nans ha war-nans an golow a wra gwan.
127 Vel, an flamm dornow hedhys 128 a wra ow tanow yn kres, ha pub tu 129 an flamm a wra ow gwanha yn keth tu;
130 ha'n kres na, gans aga eselyow a-hedhes, 131 y'm gwelas moy esel mil a angel fest, 132 pub onan ow synsi yn sklerder ha arta.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
139 Bernardo, come vide li occhi miei 140 nel caldo suo caler fissi e attenti, 141 li suoi con tanto affetto volse a lei,
142 che ’ miei di rimirar fé più ardenti.
query.result:
**English:**
139 Bernard, when he saw my eyes 140 fixed and attentive in his warm gaze, 141 turned his own to her with such affection,
142 that he made mine more ardent to look again.
**Cornish:**
139 Bernerd, pan wrug ev gweles vy lagha 140 ow pos ow tewlel yn y honys kalet, 141 ev a droas y lagha dhe'y gans affection,
142 ow teva vy lagha moyha dhe'y gweles.
